This is the final version: Correction to HIV case study in Greece featured in WHO/Europe report on social determinants of health We should also credit Media Matters for debunking the WHO claim last night, here. Meanwhile in the eurozone.... the Portuguese government has managed to get its 2014 budget through parliament - probably teeing up a series of court challenges against the latest austerity measures. A majority of MPs in Lisbon approved the budget this afternoon, while anti-austerity protesters gathered outside the parliament building. Reuters has the details: Several thousand unionists and pensioners converged in front of the building to protest the budget's public-sector wage and pension cuts, which follow tax hikes and spending cuts already under way. Inside, a small group chanted "Resign! Resign!" from the public gallery as the finance minister spoke.The ruling centre-right coalition has a comfortable majority in parliament, so the budget passed easily. But all the other parties, including the main opposition Socialists, whose government had requested the bailout in 2011, voted against.The opposition has vowed to challenge a range of key spending cuts in the Constitutional Court after the passage. "This budget will be remembered as a constitutional provocation," Socialist leader Antonio Jose Seguro told parliament shortly before the vote. The court had shot down several austerity measures, but late on Monday upheld one contested measure that increases the work week for the public sector. Still, increasing the work week to 40 hours from 35 hours will have little effect on this and next year's budget, while measures that could be challenged are worth an estimated 1.3 billion euros, or a third of all next year's budget savings. "What is certain is that key austerity measures will end up with the court, and I think it can still deliver surprises, both to those on the left and to those on the right," said Adelino Maltez, a political scientist at Lisbon's Technical University. Nicholas Spiro, managing director at Spiro Sovereign Strategy consultants in London, said the court's rulings "hang over Portugal's reform programme like a sword of Damocles". President Anibal Cavaco Silva had already begun the court process over the weekend, by asking for a review of a planned cut in public-sector pensions that make up a key part of next year's savings. That was a law separate from the budget, and the court now has 25 days to review it. Any new rejection by the court would force the government to hunt for alternative measures. The administration has repeatedly said there is no 'plan B' to find alternative revenues. But local media have reported one possibility is raising value-added tax again on many products, which could undermine an economy just recovering from its worst downturn since the 1970s. Portugal's lenders - the European Commission, the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank - have also identified challenges by the court as potentially the biggest threat to Lisbon's efforts to exit the bailout in 2014. "Six months away from the end of the programme, we are starting to get out of an emergency situation and projecting a more promising future. It's no time to give up," Finance Minister Maria Luis Albuquerque said. Nida Ali, economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, says we didn't get much clarity on forward guidance from the Bank today. She comments: The Governor and MPC members reiterated what we already knew – that they believe forward guidance is working because people are not considering an interest rate rise now and that unemployment reaching 7% is only a threshold and not an automatic trigger for a rate rise. In our view, these arguments do not hold much water. Given how far the level of GDP is below trend, it’s very unlikely that markets would be considering a rate rise now, despite the positive economic trends seen recently. Furthermore, financial markets are still likely to believe that unemployment touching 7% will lead to an increase in the interest rate. According to the Governor, his interaction with businesses suggests that they are clear on the Bank’s monetary policy stance and on forward guidance. While this could potentially encourage businesses to spend, we think it’s important for the Bank to communicate effectively to convey its message to financial markets as well. Five key points from the Bank of England's appearance at the Treasury select committee  1) Governor Mark Carney has expressed deep concern over accusations that a division of Royal Bank of Scotland deliberately undermined and destroyed business customers for profit. In his first public comments on the allegations made in two reports (one by the Bank's own former deputy governor, Sir Andrew Large), Carney said they were " both deeply troubling and extremely serious." He said: It's the direct responsibility of the FCA to conduct an appropriate investigation. I know the institution itself is conducting their own investigation but authorities need to be involved and that's absolutely necessary This has to be tracked down to the full extent of the law. Carney also dismissed the defence that RBS was under pressure to rebuild its capital reserves. There's no excuse for "predatory restructuring", he said, as: This behaviour is a fundamental violation of the integrity of the banking relationship. 2) MPs remain unconvinced by forward guidance. Perhaps Carney should consider wearing a t-shirt with "7% is a threshold, not a trigger" printed on the front, for his next appearance at parliament. Once again, the governor found himself defending his forward guidance on interest rates with the usual explanation that it provides certainty and clarity. The committee does not share Carney's view. The exchange between Carney and Brooks Newmark MP was pretty tasty. Newmark saying Carney had hurt the Bank's credibility, and promptly accused of "a total failure of logic". Ee'll find out in 2014 or 2015 who is right. 3) Is the Office for National Statistics fit for purpose? Committee chairman Andrew Tyrie had stinging criticism for the ONS, saying that the statistics body was failing to provide the Bank of England with the data it needed. Carney conceded that the situation could be better. Here's his full reply (via Reuters) There's been an adjustment in the last six months or so to the deflator used to translate from nominal to real investment. And the consequences of that has been that the picture of investment, both historically and present, has changed quite substantially, and actually the path of investment in the UK is now much more volatile apparently than it is in other major advanced economies. We have put cautionary language in our reports in August and in November in terms of how much weight we're putting on that data. We're not putting full weight on that data and it has to be said that it doesn't entirely feel right that investment is, as measured, falling at a time when we see continued strengthening investment intention. There is a lot of work, it would appear, that needs to be done to bring the flow of funds data here up to the international standards and to the level that we need. And then the real blow: I was much more comfortable with the data in Canada. 4) Carney's upbeat talks has raised Westminster hackles With an election just 18 months away, Labour may be concerned that the chancellor becoming a Tory cheerleader. John Mann MP was fairly blunt in criticising governor for declaring two weeks ago that the recovery was gathering pace, without acknowledging the time it has taken to reach here and the debts which have been incurred en route. Carney may have grinned when he flatly denied nursing political ambitions (there have been rumours), but there was no levity by the end of the exchange when he said he was "more than mildly offended". Labour members of the committee also voiced concerns about a pro-City speech Carney gave in October, to mark 125 years of the Financial Times. Future comments from the governor will be closely scrutinised as polling day approaches.... 5) Carney is eager to get his hands on a leverage ratio for UK banks. The opening exchange focused on this morning's news that George Osborne has asked the Bank's Financial Policy Committee should start reviewing the 'leverage ratio' (controls on how much capital a UK bank should hold, relative to its lending) now, rather than in four years time. Carney said he believed leverage ratios were a great way of avoiding financial meltdown, saying: If I could pick one element that was essential to the performance of the Canadian banking system during the crisis it was the presence of a leverage ratio. We see that this power is consistent and in fact necessary to properly implement a robust capital framework in the United Kingdom. Andrea Leadsom's final question to Mark Carney didn't get into the blog at the time. She reminded the governor that the Bank's senior ranks exclude half the population (they're all male). Would he like a list of 100 highly capable women who could bolster its expertise? Carney says that he welcomes recommendations from "anyone" to "reinforce human capital" at the BoE, adding that gender imbalance is a key part of a review taking place now into how it runs. And that was the end of the session, after more than two and a half-hours of questioning. Andrew Tyrie's opening remark at 10am hat the meeting might occupy "most of the morning" proved a little conservative. Harder than it looks, forward guidance...... Round-up of the key points to follow. A reminder that highlights start here. And you can see a playback of the whole session here. And finally, Mark Carney gets the Scottish question. Andrea Leadsom MP asks the Bank of England governor for his views on Alex Salmond's plan for independence, in which Scotland would keep the pound but run its own fiscal policies. Can you squeeze two fiscal plans into one currency? Carney tries to wriggle out of it, saying that he's been "riveted" to his duties to the Treasury Committee and hasn't had time to digest Salmond's proposals which were announced this morning (liveblog here). That won't satisfy Leadsom, who gently insists that Carney shares his wisdom. So, the Bank of England governor answers the question - framing his reply within the context of the eurozone crisis. He says there are "many lessons from the crisis period" which show the kind of attributes a currency union needs to be successful. That includes "some fiscal federalism", says Carney, citing the proposed eurozone banking union as a step along the way. Ultimately, in the fullness of time, more fiscal federalism will be needed to create a fully viable euro, Carney concludes. He makes no direct comment on the Scottish situation -- goodness knows what John Mann would have concluded about Carney's political ambitions if he had! Over to Andrea Leadsom MP, who asks whether the eurozone can ever fully recover without proper banking union. Spencer Dale, the Bank of England's chief economist, replies that the best hope for the eurozone is weak growth over the next few years, regardless of the situation in its banks. But can you ever have a successful currency union without full fiscal union? Dale replies that you can, in certain circumstances, and they are "political circumstances" not economic ones. On how the Bank's QE programme will be unwound -- deputy governor Charlie Bean says it will not start to sell gilts until it sees a sustained recovery. It may not happen 'just after' the first interest rate rise. On the housing market, Carney strikes an upbeat tone - saying that there are signs of momentum spreading from London and the South East. He concedes that housing starts remain low -- in Canada*, he says, the rate is twice as high even though the population is half the size. That supply issue - whether it's a lack of builders, a lack of land, a lack of bricks - needs solving. There's a lot more space in Canada, mind you, he adds. * - is Carney getting nostalgic for home after more than two hours in the Thatcher Room? Andrew Tyrie returns Mark Carney to his comment that the former deputy governor Sir Andrew Large first became aware no more than six weeks ago that RBS might have been deliberately hurting small firms. We have been hearing complaints from constituents for much longer than that, governor, Tyrie says. Carney (who joined the bank in the summer), agrees that it would be "remarkable" and "shocking" that RBS's treatment of small firms wasn't picked up earlier if, as feared, it took place on a wide scale. Tyrie: Isn't this a failure of governance, at at time when we're being told that governance is being cleaned up? Governor Carney says that reforming the 'senior person's regime' (how bankers in influential positions) is a key target for the Bank, and also the FSA watchdog. John Mann MP goes on to ask Mark Carney what ambitions he has in the political field. Carney grins, and replies: None, none whatsoever, thank you. That's followed by a clash over Carney's claim that the UK recovery is stronger than other advanced economies. That's just wrong, Mann says, citing India and China. They're not advanced economies, Charlie Bean points out. Mann then cites OECD and IMF data that the US is growing faster - Carney denies it. Mann: you're sounding more like a politican than a governor Carney: No, I'm making sure the record is accurate It all turns a little nasty in the Thatcher Room, with Mann pointing out that the UK's recovery is simply later than other countries, and driven by rising indebtedness. He suggests that Carney is acting as a cheerleader for the government, contrasting him to Mervyn King who was much less optimistic about the economy. Carney says he's "more than mildly offended" by the thrust of Mann's question, that he's too close to the chancellor, George Osborne. Mervyn King, he adds, had plenty of reasons for pessimism - including a recession, and high inflation. The picture is different today. John Mann MP asks when Sir Andrew Large, the former deputy governor of the Bank of England, first alerted Mark Carney to his concerns over RBS. It was a month, or six weeks ago, he replies. That's also when the FCA was notified, Carney adds. Could RBS could have been forced into cutting healthy firms adrift, as is alleged, because of the pressure to cut its lending book and recapitalise? Mark Carney says this is no defence at all for the kind of "predatory restructuring" that RBS is accused of. If true, this behaviour is a fundamental violation of banking integrity and the 'banking relationship'. Bank of England governor Mark Carney says the latest allegations against Royal Bank of Scotland are deeply worrying, and should be pursued fully by independent authorities. Asked by the Treasury committee for his views on yesterday's report from Lawrence Tomlinson, which suggested that RBS had deliberately driven healthy firms to the wall, Carney replied: We take the view that the behaviours documented in the report [and in a separate report from Sir Andrew Large] are deeply troubling and extremely serious. It is the direct responsibility of the FCA to investigate, Carney continued, saying that RBS can't be left to simply look into it themselves. Authorities need to be involved, he added. Could this actions from RBS have contributed to the UK's weak productivity? Carney says that it would have had some impact on a macro-economic level, which underlines how the allegations must be "tracked down to the full extent of the law". However, Carney doesn't believe the scale of what apparently went on would have hit "overall productivity". Onto the question of zombie companies - firms who are clinging onto life because monetary policy is so loose. Ben Broadbent says that loose policy has been a good thing overall, and suggests that some viable firms might have been swept away by it. Mark Carney chips in too - saying that as the recovery picks up, the lost opportunity of supporting zombie firms rather than healthier ones increases. MPC member Ben Broadbent challenges the validity of the data showing that massively more loans go to financial firms (24%) than factories (1.4%). Much of the former is 'rolling over' loans rather than funding new expansion, he says. George Mudie MP wants to know what the Bank is doing to get more loans to small firms. Why isn't it more concerned that the government's Funding for Lending scheme appears to be driving mortgage lending over SME loans? Carney indicates that we'll get more details on this issue on Thursday, when the Bank's Financial Policy Committee holds its own press conference. Mark Carney being challenged again over his October speech (online here) in which he said that financial services should remain at the heart of the UK economy. George Mudie MP criticises this "lauding" of the City, and reminds the governor of recent figures showing that 24% of lending goes to other financial institutions, 43% to housing, 10% to real estate, and just 1.4% to manufacturing. Aren't we going down the same old road as before the crash? Another long answer from Carney - the point seemed to be that it's important that Britain has a robust financial system, robust banks..... and we are seeing improvements being made. Back to productivity, and Mark Carney says that international prospects aren't as rosy as the bank would like. The eurozone is effectively stagnating, he says, while emerging market growth has been revised down. In that case, asks David Ruffley MP, how long can consumers provide the impetus for the UK recovery without creating problems for the future? Carney explains that consumer demand will help stimulate business investment -- but admits that unless we get overseas demand, the recovery will be rather modest. Andrew Tyrie asks whether the Bank of England is happy with the quality of data it receives from the Office for National Statistics. Carney struggles to respond at first (we get an umm, and a  ), before suggesting that we can all improve. Tyrie demands a better answer - suggesting the governor should stop talking in code and say whether he's happy or not. Carney says he has been struck by the "challenges" posed for policy setting in some areas by the official data. The bank isn't putting the "full weight" on the ONS's official investment data. The data on how funds flow between different parts of the UK needs to be brought up to international standards, he adds. In short, the governor says, there is room for improvement. Killer question from Tyrie -- Was it better in Canada? I was much more comfortable with the data in Canada (where he was governor before being plucked to run Threadneedle Street), Carney replies . So the answer is yes? Pretty much, Carney concedes. Deputy governor Charlie Bean tries to ride to the ONS's defence, saying that its resources have been squeezed by the recession. It may not be as good as it was. Tyrie suggests that the ONS is providing inaccurate, out of date data -- and asks the Bank to write to him with their recommendations to improve the situation. Ben Broadbent (an 'external' member of the bank's monetary policy committee) also offered support for Carney's forward guidance, saying he personally signed up "lock, stock and barrel", and does not see inflationary dangers. John Thurso MP makes an interesting point, on whether the productivity problems in the UK stem from the City sucking the brightest minds into it, rather than industry. Thurso says he visited Rolls-Royce recently, and were told that it only managed to hire 700 people of the calibre it needed because of the recession. A reminder that the session is online, here. Deputy governor Charlie Bean is now at the crease, fielding questions about the output gap in the UK economy. Bean says that productivity is the "single biggest puzzle" about the UK economy today, suggesting that the Bank's brightest minds are still trying to understand why productivity was so weak since the crisis began. He adding that "we have no idea how big the output gap is" - which makes it hard to understand how the economy will behave as the recovery picks up. The key thing with our forward guidance on interest rate rises, Bean insists, isn't growth, it's whether we can see a significant pick-up in slack. Carney is asked about a Reuters poll that found a majority of economists think the handling of forward guidance (which he introduced, of course, in his early days at the Bank) has hurt the Bank's credibility. The governor replies that he's not familiar with the poll*, but shoots back with another poll that shows three quarters of people understand that the 7% unemployment target is a threshold, not a trigger. As Carney put it, in another gloves-off moment: Let's flesh out who's confused about this. The markets, he suggests, have not priced in an interest rate rise in a way they would have done without forward guidance (given recent decent economic data) * - there are details here, governor. Spencer Dale is also backing forward guidance on interest rates, saying people in the real economy appreciate the increased certainty it gives. They don't worry that we'll raise rates until conditions are better, or raise them quickly them when we start. He also cites spare capacity in the economy as another reason to hold rates. Are you moving away from using the unemployment rate as the main target? Dale says not. Chief economist, Spencer Dale, denies that the Bank has given up on targeting inflation -- in a recent speech, he admitted it could be a double-edged sword. Brooks Newmark challenges Carney, pointing out that the forecasts in the latest inflation report show a 40% chance that the unemployment rate will drop to 7% by the final quarter of 2014. That's nine month's earlier than the Bank thought in August. "How much damage has this caused to the Bank's credibility", asks Newmark, suggesting that Carney's forward guidance was already "dead on arrival". Carney is highly unamused and unimpressed, replying: That is a total failure of logic, Mr Newmark. Carney repeats his usual defence of his pledge not to consider a rate rise until the unemployment market has improved -- that it gives households, firms, market participants a view of the conditions that the Bank needs to see before considering a rate rise. We are not going to pull the rug out from under the recovery before it gets going. Carney goes on to point out that many workers would rather work longer hours -- that top-line figure of 7.6% doesn't always tell the full story. The 7% unemployment target in our forward guidance is a threshold for considering a rate rise, not a trigger, Carney adds. Onto forward guidance, and a question from Brooks Newmark MP. Does the recent fall in the unemployment rate to 7.6% in the third quarter of 2013, faster than the Bank's earlier forecasts, means an interest rate rise is more imminent than we though? Carney welcomes the fall in joblessness, towards the 7% target set by forward guidance. But no, it does not change the guidance - and he wouldn't get carried away by unofficial data showing that the rate fell to 7.1% in September alone. Andrew Tyrie asks whether Carney was consciously setting a new tone from his predecessor in his speech in October on how the BoE will deal with the financial sector. Carney give a long answer, saying that his strategy builds on Lord King's legacy. But he creates the impression, certainly in Tyrie's mind, that the short answer was 'yes'. This speech is online here. Do we really want such a large UK financial sector anyway, asks Pat McFadden, harking back to the problems Britain suffered after 2008 from an unbalanced economy. Carney claims that a big, strong City is good for us all. The jobs created are spread across the country, he claims. The City helps UK firms penetrate international markets by giving them capital. It does help our creative industries by funding new markets. And it is positive for exports -- covering some of the UK's large deficit in goods trading. McFadden homes in on this with a double-whammy of facts -- 50% of the lending goes to property of one form or another, while just 1.4% goes to manufacturing. This is affecting the characteristics of the UK economy, surely? Carney doesn't accept that a properly-run financial services affects the rest of the economy. What other powers would help protect the UK banking sector, asks Pat McFadden MP, reminding Carney of a recent speech on the future of the UK financial sector. 1) Ending "Too big to fail -- including changing the capital structures of the largest banks. So that debt holders are also exposed to losses, after shareholders, to avoid taxpayers picking up the bill. These are the same BAIL-IN powers that are getting a lot of attention in the euro area. 2) Ensuring resilience in the various financial markets that simply ceased functioning when the 2008 crash struck. They need to keep working in such circumstances (as the equity markets did, allowing shares to tumble rather than trading simply ceasing) McFadden isn't too impressed, suggesting it's all too esoteric for the man in the street. Carney insists that both points are important. If an institution makes a mistake, it should bear the full consequences. We need to make changes to really end Too Big To Fail. And fixing the "plumbing" of the financial markets will also help avoid a repeat of the credit crunch. Get it wrong, and the size of the UK's financial services industry will suffer. Andrew Tyrie wants more details on the timing -- will the BoE's FPC have these powers by June 2015? Carney says he expects it within this parliament (which should indeed end then). So, as far as the bank is concerned, is the transfer of power a "done deal" subject to parliamentary approval, Tyrie asks. Carney agrees, saying that this would be "consistent and necessary" to maintain capital levels. But, Tyrie says, producing Osborne's letter (on which the printer ink may still be dripping), the chancellor is asking "whether" the FPC should have these powers as well as how. He suggests Carney has ignored the first part and moved onto the second part. Tyrie asks Carney to explain this morning's exchange of letters about the leverage ratio (see earlier post). The governor explains that that Bank has agreed to hold a review on the implementation of a leverage ratio on UK banks. The 'expedited' review will have three elements: 1) whether to have one. The Bank's view is that it's an integral part of bank regulation -- Carney says it helped protect banks in Canada. 2) How it should change related to the risk-based capital of banks -- Should it change related to issues such as 'ring-fencing banks' (splitting casino banking away from high street banking). Carney reckons it should- rather than being a fixed 3% limit 3) Timing. How the UK's implementation of these rules should fit with other countries. Some issues are still being discussed in international forums, including how "bailin-able debt" will interacts with other debt on the books. Most of these factors should be resolved in the next three quarters, says Carney, who adds that he welcomes the Chancellor's approach today. And we're off, with chairman Andrew Tyrie warning that we have "a lot of ground to go over". It could take all morning..... A reminder that we'll be hearing from Dr Mark Carney, Governor, Charlie Bean, Deputy Governor, Monetary Policy, Spencer Dale, Executive Director and Chief Economist, and Dr Ben Broadbent, Member, Monetary Policy Committee, Bank of England The Treasury committee hearing in the Thatcher Room is about to start -- it's being live-streamed here Interesting.... the Treasury has announced that it has asked the Bank of England to review the leverage ratio being imposed on UK banks. And the tone of George Osborne's letter to Mark Carney suggests that the chancellor may not want higher ratios imposed in the UK than abroad -- another sign that Mervyn King's legacy at the Bank is unravelling? Leverage ratios effectively measure a bank's lending relative to capital available to cover losses. Under the Basel 3 rules, banks must maintain a minimum "leverage ratio" of 3%, by 2019. Lord King, in his final days at the Bank, pushed the target date to be brought forward, and also suggested he'd support a rather higher ratio. In his letter to Carney, Osborne asked the Bank's FPC to assess what powers it needs over the leverage ratio. He added that he believes the UK should be in line with international rules, and the international timescale. If the FPC wants a higher leverage ratio, or an earlier implementation, Osborne wants to see "clear evidence" that it will improve UK financial security. In his reply, Carney agreed that the time is right to review leverage ratios. Leverage ratios have also caught the eye of the Treasury committee -- so Mark Carney may get a question on that too. Economic news from Italy -- consumer confidence has risen this month, after taking a nasty dip in October, but people are more worried about future economic prospects. ISTAT reports that its consumer morale index rose to 98.3, up from 97.3, with people reporting their view of the current economic climate, and unemployment, had improved. However, sentiment on future outlook deteriorated. Italy's economy has been shrinking for the last nine quarters, with a 0.1% drop in GDP in the third quarter of this year. Statement here. Not much else to report in the markets this morning. The FTSE 100 has dipped a little, down 14 points at 6680, while the French and German markets are flat. Overnight, the Nikkei fell 0.6% while the Chinese markets slipped slightly. IG's Stan Shamu blamed "a lull phase as uncertainty and caution prevail along with some mild profit taking". Hugo Boss is also blaming problems in China for disappointing profit forecasts. The German fashion chain's chief exec told investors in Hong Kong this morning that it won't hit its target of €750m operating profits until 2015, not next year as planned. Shares in Hugo Boss have dropped by 3.5% in early trading. CEO Claus-Dietrich Lahrs called China a "particular concern", admitting that the days of rampant growth in its luxury goods market were over.... Apologies for the earlier typo, and many thanks to the rival journalist - and baerchen below - for flagging it up. Rémy Cointreau's shares have slumped by 7.5% after the drinks firm gave investors a nasty hangover, reporting disappointing demand in the key Chinese market. The cognac and spirits firm admitted that it expects to suffer a "substantial double-digit decline" in operating profits in the current financial year. It blamed a slowdown in China, and the tricky economic climate in Europe, saying: In an uncertain economic environment in Europe and against the backdrop of a sharp slowdown in China, which remains impacted by high inventory levels in distribution and poor short-term visibility, the business environment will be less favourable in the second half of the year. Rémy Cointreau's operating profits have already fallen by 7.3% in the first six months of this financial year, including a 10% drop in sales of Rémy Martin (again, China gets the blame). The latest word is that profits could be down by a fifth by the end of the year: 08:50:11RTRS - REMY COINTREAU RCOP.PA SAYS EXPECTS FULL YEAR OPERATING PROFIT TO DECLINE BY 20 PCT OR SLIGHTLY MORE - CEO RCOP.PA Other drinks firms are also suffering -- with SAB Miller leading the fallers on the FTSE 100, down 1.7%. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, is up before MPs this morning to answer questions on the Bank's view of the UK economy. Officially, Carney and colleagues will be updating the Treasury select committee on the Bank's latest quarterly inflation report, which declared that the UK's economic recovery was becoming more secure. As Carney put it two weeks ago: For the first time in a long time, you don't have to be an optimist to see the glass as half full. But we also expect a few tough questions on Carney's precious 'forward guidance' - that the bank won't consider raising interest rates until the jobs market improves. The Treasury committee didn't seem too impressed with the whole notion the last time they quizzed the governor. And surely Andrew Tyrie, committee chair, will seek Carney's views on some of the latest problems to hit the UK banking sector -- from the crisis at Co-op Bank to the allegations that RBS deliberately brought small firms down to make a profits. Deputy governor Charlie Bean, chief economist Spencer Dale, and MPC member Ben Broadbent are also attending. The session starts at 10am GMT. Britain's energy market is also in focus today, with my colleague Terry Macalister reporting that RWE npower has pulled out of a huge offshore windfarm in the Bristol Channel. A blow to the UK's environmental ambitions, and raising the prospect that green subsidies (levied via energy bills) may need to be raised to make such projects more viable. £4bn wind turbine plan axed in green energy blow The chief exec of Ofgem may get a few questions on the issue when he appears before MPs this morning -- a day after a report found total profits and profit margins rose last year. Elsewhere.... in the financial markets, most of Monday's initial enthusiasm over the Iranian nuclear deal has now dissipated, with oil and gold bouncing back from yesterday's lows. As Kit Juckes of Societe Generale remarked: +1 We'll also have our usual focus on Greece. As we covered in last night's live blog, the country's finance minister has vowed to reach a deal with its troika of lenders before it takes over the EU presidency in January. Still not clear how the difference of opinion over Greece's fiscal gap in 2014 will be resolved. I"ll be tracking all the developments through the day, focusing on Mark Carney's hearing from 10am.

webTitle: Osborne asks Mark Carney to consider extra powers to curb bank risk-taking

fields.standfirst: Chancellor asks governor to review leverage ratios for banks – an indicator of their financial health
fields.body:
George Osborne has asked the Bank of England to consider bringing in extra powers to curb risk-taking by banks, a move described by Labour as the chancellor's second U-turn in as many days.

A day after Osborne announced a legal cap on the cost of payday loans, he asked Bank governor Mark Carney to review leverage ratios for banks – an indicator of their financial health that measures how much capital underpins their loans. A leverage ratio of 3%, for example, means a bank can lend up to £33 for each pound of capital it holds in reserve.

The chancellor asked the Bank's financial policy committee for a 12-month review to consider tougher curbs on banks' risk-taking than exist in other countries.

His announcement, published as an exchange of letters in which Carney agrees "the time is now right to commission such a review", comes as the House of Lords debates the banking reform bill, which contains a series of measures intended to overhaul Britain's banks in the wake of the financial crisis and the Libor rate-fixing scandal.

Writing to Carney, Osborne said: "Now is an appropriate time for the FPC to consider whether and when it needs any additional powers and how any new powers would fit in with the rest of its macro-prudential 'tool-kit'."

But Cathy Jamieson, Labour's shadow financial secretary, said the timing was no coincidence and she accused Osborne of changing tack because he knew he would lose a vote over recommendations in a high-profile parliamentary report to make banks financially stronger through tightening the leverage ratio.

"After his sudden U-turn on payday loans, George Osborne is once again bowing to pressure in order to head off an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords.

"Rather than showing the leadership we need to radically reform the banks, George Osborne is reluctantly backing down in the face of arguments from Labour and the Parliamentary Commission. It was right for the Parliamentary Commission to insist that leverage ratio direction powers should be given to the Bank of England and the Chancellor has calculated he would lose the vote on this."

Speaking to the cross-party Treasury Select Committee today, Canadian Carney appeared to endorse the use of leverage ratios.

"If I could pick one element that was essential to the performance of the Canadian banking system during the crisis it was the presence of a leverage ratio," he said.

Carney also told the committee that he found reports that bailed out Royal Bank of Scotland was deliberately wrecking viable small businesses to make profits "both deeply troubling and extremely serious" and said they needed to be investigated fully.

He also defended the BoE's scheme of forward guidance, under which policymakers say they will not consider raising interest rates until at least an unemployment threshold of 7% is reached. Carney said his meetings with more than 200 businesses in recent months as well as surveys from financial markets, suggested there was a widespread understanding of the scheme and that is was helping the recovery by giving people confidence. Having been repeatedly questioned on the issue he retorted: "Let's flesh out who's confused."

He also had some stern words for British statisticians, saying that official data was not as robust as the Bank required on investment.

"We're not putting full weight on that data and it has to be said that it doesn't entirely feel right that investment is, as measured, falling at a time when we see continued strengthening investment intention," he said. He also raised concerns about flow of funds data.

"I was much more comfortable with the data in Canada," added Carney, who was governor of the Bank of Canada before taking the helm at the BoE in July.

A spokesperson for the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said: "ONS seeks to ensure all of its economic statistics meet the highest standards. ONS is examining ways to produce new statistics on the flow of funds between various sectors of the economy. ONS maintains a regular dialogue with the Bank of England and welcomes all views on how ONS's statistics can better meet the needs of users."

webTitle: Men's Wearhouse and Joseph A Bank: suited to each other?

fields.standfirst: Two biggest retailers of men's formalwear are looking to merge as they fight to cut costs in an ever more casual world
fields.body:
It’s tuxedo time. The time of year when men whose usual idea of formalwear is chinos and a tie have to dash off to the nearest rental shop to suit up for black tie events. As the season gets into full swing, the two biggest retailers in formalwear are in a slow dance of their own, looking to merge as they fight to cut costs in an ever more casual world.

Men’s Wearhouse, which runs 1,137 menswear outlets across the US, has offered to buy its smaller century-old rival Joseph A Bank for over $1.5bn. The bid comes after Jos A Bank, as it styles itself, made its own, unsolicited, $2.3bn offer for its Houston-based rival in early October.

Back then, Men’s Wearhouse rejected Jos A Bank’s offer, arguing it was taking advantage of a share price slip following a slow quarter. But the retailer left the door open for possible talks in the future. In an unusual tactic during the takeover bid, Jos A Bank chairman Robert Wildrick said his company would be receptive to being bought by Men's Wearhouse instead of acquiring its rival.

Now his wish has come true. Bill Sechrest, lead director of Men's Wearhouse, said Tuesday the deal had “a strategic logic and the potential to deliver substantial benefits to our respective shareholders, employees and customers."

“Together, we can create the premier men's apparel retailer, with enhanced scale and a broader best-in-class offering for our valued customers, which we expect to drive significant shareholder value," said Doug Ewert, president and chief executive officer of Men's Wearhouse.

While the dance continues, some retail analysts are wondering whether the two parties have had a few too many pre-dinner martinis. “It’s insane,” said veteran retail consultant Howard Davidowitz, chairman of Davidowitz & Associates.

“When you make an acquisition, you want to carve out a new growth area,” he said. “This isn’t a retail deal, it’s a real estate deal. All they are doing is buying the other retailer's property portfolio.”

“The bottom line here is formal. One company, Men’s Wearhouse, does a better job than the other. The theory is they will add more formal expertise to Jos A Banks. But so what?” he said.

Davidowitz also argues that the combined entity may face competition issues. When Whole Foods bought smaller rival Wild Oats in 2007, the federal trade commission stepped in arguing the deal eliminate “the substantial competition between these two uniquely close competitors.” The deal was held up for years and Whole Foods eventually sold the chain.

“They’ll argue that Macy’s and others are all in formalwear, but Whole Foods made the same points about WalMart and others,” said Davidowitz.

The main advantage of a deal will be cost-cutting in a tough sales environment. Jos A Bank has more than 600 stores, about half as many as Men's Wearhouse. The two would be able to combine back office functions such as purchasing and close unprofitable stores while keeping a wide geographic spread. Men’s Wearhouse said Tuesday it would save $100m to $150m in “synergies” through improving purchasing, optimizing customer service and marketing practices, and streamlining corporate functions.

The proposed deal comes after a tumultuous spat in Men's Wearhouse’s boardroom. In June, George Zimmer, the retailer's chairman, was ousted from the company he co-founded 40 years ago. The gravel-voiced Zimmer was the face of Men’s Wearhouse and famous for TV ads and his catchphrase: “You’re going to like the way you look. I guarantee it.”

The board said Zimmer had wanted full control of the company. After he was ousted Zimmer hit back saying he had argued against the direction the company was taking and "the board has inappropriately chosen to silence my concerns."

webTitle: Europe needs a Roma working class | George Soros

fields.standfirst: Roma represent more than 20% of new entrants into the labour force in the European Union's newest member states but their living conditions have actually deteriorated since many of them became EU citizens
fields.body:
Across Europe, millions are suffering from unemployment and the prospect of a long period of economic stagnation. But no group has been harder hit than the Roma.

There are more than 10 million Roma living in Europe, mostly concentrated in the Balkans and in the European Union's newest member states, especially Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, and Hungary. What is truly shocking is that their living conditions have actually deteriorated since many of them became EU citizens. At the same time, the majority population's attitude has become more hostile almost everywhere in Europe.

The two trends are mutually reinforcing: marginalisation breeds contempt, and vice versa. The only escape from this trap is investment in education, which would pay enormous social dividends.

Consider, for example, that Roma represent more than 20% of new entrants into the labour force in the countries above.

The good news is that we know how to prepare Roma children to be productive members of society. My foundations have been active in educating Roma for more than 25 years. Over that period, we have educated a small cohort of young Roma who retain their identity and yet can break the hostile stereotypes held by those with whom they interact.

Together with the World Bank, we established the Roma Education Fund in 2005. The REF is ready to help national education authorities across the EU improve their performance in educating Roma children. Indeed, its programmes currently reach more than 100,000 students each year, including more than 1,600 university students who receive scholarships.

But these numbers are woefully inadequate relative to the magnitude of the problem. Half of the Roma are of school age, and the population is growing faster than the capacity of the REF. The fund's annual budget is only €12m (£10m), of which my foundations cover nearly half, and we find it difficult to secure additional funds. That is unacceptable. The programmes developed by the REF ought to be scaled up by governments, with the help of the EU, and made available to all Roma children in Europe.

The European commission has played a very helpful role through its structural funds, which cover up to 80% of the additional costs involved in integrating the Roma. Unfortunately, the remaining 20% is difficult to mobilise, owing to widespread anti-Roma sentiment throughout Europe.

To break the negative stereotypes, Roma children must be educated to celebrate and take pride in their Roma heritage. That is what the REF has done. As it is, educated Roma do not fit the stereotypes, so they can easily blend into the majority population, but the majority's hostility remains. If the approach developed by the REF were generally adopted, it would go a long way toward breaking the stereotypes.

But education is not enough. The Roma must also be able to find employment. A lasting solution requires Europe to build a Roma working class. Here the private sector also has a role to play.

Experts from the European Commission and from my foundations are developing a demonstration project to make private sector internships available to Roma youth enrolled in vocational schools.

Romania already has a similar programme for the majority population, and minister of education Remus Pricopie has pledged to open it up to the Roma. I urge other governments to take similar steps.

Let's be honest: there is a Roma problem in Europe, and it is getting worse. But both the problem and its worsening reflect a toxic combination of deep-seated hostility and persistent neglect.

In fact, Europe's educated Roma are proving every day that the problem is eminently solvable. But solving it will take more than a generation, and Europe cannot afford to wait for economic recovery. On the contrary, given the increase in its Roma population, Europe's long-term prosperity depends on reversing current trends – and getting started right away.

• George Soros is chairman of Soros Fund Management and of the Open Society Foundations.

webTitle: Gatwick boss calls for end to airport expansion delays

fields.standfirst: Gatwick chief Stewart Wingate claims a new runway at Heathrow would sound 'death knell' for low-cost flying
fields.body:
The boss of Gatwick has called on the Airports Commission to narrow down the possible new runways in the south-east to just two options in its interim report next month – and to put air fares and pollution at the heart of its thinking.

The commission chair, Sir Howard Davies, has indicated he will eliminate the more outlandish proposals of the dozens submitted for airport expansion, but Gatwick's chief executive, Stewart Wingate, claimed a tighter shortlist was needed to eliminate unnecessary delay.

Wingate claimed that only Gatwick and Heathrow were serious contenders for current development, but low fares depended on Gatwick getting an extra runway. He said: "If Heathrow builds its runway, it will be the death knell of low-cost flying for a generation."

Arguing that the public purse and consent would only support one extra runway in the short term, he said that London Stansted airport – whose eventual expansion Gatwick backs – was far from capacity and did not have the mix of long-haul traditional airlines and low-cost carriers of Gatwick.

He added: "Boris Island is sinking without trace, and there isn't the volume at Stansted to make the case.

"Heathrow can't serve low-cost airlines. They're restricted to legacy airlines. They are already the highest charging airport in the world."

Gatwick is seeking permission to build a second runway. Local opponents say expansion would destroy many listed buildings and massively expand noise in the area.

However, the county councils of Sussex and Kent have indicated they would not oppose a new runway after 2019 when a current agreement to limit growth expires.

Wingate added: "We strike a fine balance of serving passenger demand of legacy, charter and low-cost air travel. Is Sir Howard going to give them low fares and minimise the environmental impact or give them high fares and poor air quality? The sooner he narrows it down further, the better the chance of building a new runway in the south-east."

Gatwick announced a 10% jump in turnover for the first six months of 2013, up to £360.6m, and a 20% leap in profits after tax to £98.2m, although 2012's comparative figures were dented by the Olympics.

Underlying passenger numbers were up 3.5% year on year, mainly from European short-haul services.

webTitle: Youth unemployment will lead to widespread poverty in old age – OECD

fields.standfirst: Pensions built on monthly contributions will be undermined if workers are unemployed for long periods, says thinktank
fields.body:
High levels of youth unemployment will lead to widespread poverty in old age as young people struggle to save for retirement, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

A new breed of private pension schemes, which are built on monthly contributions, will be undermined if younger workers stay unemployed for long periods, said the Paris-based thinktank.

As it warned that babies born today will live until 100 years of age on average and retire at 70, the OECD said the weakness of the British state-funded system meant workers in the UK were among the most vulnerable.

Stefano Scarpetta, an employment specialist at the OECD, said: "It is of great concern that many countries are building contributory pension systems when they have large numbers of unemployed young people who cannot contribute and will have very low retirement incomes."

His comments came as the OECD said that on most measures, the UK ranks in the bottom half of the pensions league table. Public expenditure on pensioner benefits as a proportion of GDP is lower than the average. Pensioner living standards are also below the OECD average. Italy has the highest spending on pensions as a proportion of GDP whereas the Netherlands, which has a large private and workplace pensions top up, has the highest standard of living for retirees.

To tackle long-standing weaknesses in the UK retirement system, the thinktank said the government has one of the most comprehensive pension reform programmes in the developed world.

While other countries have focused on tackling the growing burden of future pension costs by raising the state pension age or improving incentives for older workers to stay in the jobs market, the UK has pursued every avenue to both improve the lives of older people and cut the cost of providing them with a decent income, said the OECD.

The Paris-based organisation said in its report Pensions at a Glance 2013 that the UK had raised the average incomes of people above the retirement age and introduced plans to expand coverage through the workplace pension savings scheme Nest, which is expected to automatically enrol 10 million workers over the next three years.

But it said the knock-on effect of policy reforms, many of which protect the benefits accrued by older workers at the expense of young employees, was that in many OECD member countries younger workers were now more at risk of poverty than retirees.

"Pension reforms made during the past two decades lowered the pension promise for workers who enter the labour market today. Working longer may help to make up part of the reductions, but every year of contribution toward future pensions generally results in lower benefits than before the reforms," it said.

"The reduction of old-age poverty has been one of the greatest social policy successes in OECD countries. In 2010, the average poverty rate among the elderly was 12.8%, down from 15.1% in 2007, despite the Great Recession. In many OECD countries, the risk of poverty is higher at younger ages."

The report says many countries have failed to construct adequate protection for low earners. In the UK, the voluntary Nest scheme, which has proved popular with employees in the small number of companies to use it so far, could leave many people without the top-up retirement provision experts believe will be needed to have a decent standard of living in 20 or 30 years time.

The OECD points out that personal pensions based on stock market returns favoured by British politicians have inherent risks and may fail to deliver adequate returns over the longer term. Young people who cannot contribute in their early working life will find their retirement incomes suffer badly.

It said Poland and Hungary had ditched schemes that rely on stock market returns while the UK, the Czech Republic and Israel have expanded them.

In many countries older workers have come to see their homes as a potential source of income in retirement, whether following a sale or through equity release. The OECD said it was not clear how prevalent or effective housing would be to boost incomes and countries needed to "explore in greater detail how housing and financial wealth can contribute to the adequacy of retirement incomes".

The thinktank also highlighted the benefit of public services to retirees and especially lower income groups. It said governments needed to win public support for public service provision that allows older people to continue working and living a decent life.

"Public support is set to play an increasingly important role in preventing old-age poverty among people requiring health and long-term care services," it said.

A rise in the retirement age to 67 in the UK means state expenditure is only expected to increase by 0.5% over the next 40 years to 8.2% of GDP, well below the OECD average of 11.7%.

webTitle: Ofgem not a 'toothless tiger' in fight against rising energy prices, insists boss

fields.bodyText: Ofgem boss Andrew Wright says he understands public anger at rising energy prices but has denied his organisation is guilty of "feeble regulation". Wright acknowledged "deep distrust" of the big six energy companies – British Gas, npower, SSE, Scottish Power, E.ON and EDF – as some customers face price rises of more than 10% as winter kicks in. Addressing MPs on the Commons energy and climate change committee, Wright said rising prices, years of aggressive doorstep selling, confusing tariffs and complexity when consumers wanted to switch providers had all created negative perceptions of the industry. "I completely understand why people feel frustrated and angry about rising energy bills. Prices have more than doubled over the last 10 years at a time when incomes have been squeezed, and consumers are not convinced that price increases that they see are either fair or justified," he said. "Consumers have a perception that the market is not working well and that's something that we agree with. We think the retail market is not working as well as it should do." When asked whether Ofgem was a "toothless tiger", failing to address rising prices and accusations of unfair profit taking among companies, he said it was acting within its statutory regulatory framework and rejected the idea he was supportive of the rises. "I never said it was OK. I have not said this level of profit is right or acceptable. If companies imply we think 5% is right, we've never said that." He said that politicians were right to debate the issue of rising energy price rises but when questioned about Labour leader Ed Miliband's promise to freeze prices he did not appear to be enthusiastic. "The sort of things we would consider are, does it have an adverse impact on consumers and on the investment that's needed? "It is obviously necessary to allow companies to recover the revenues that they need to be able to run their businesses effectively. They should have no guarantee of profits but an efficient business serving customers should be able to recover the costs that they incur. So any arrangement that doesn't allow them to do that potentially puts at risk investment in the industry." His comments came a day after Ofgem published a report which found that profits per customer rose by 77% last year, from £30 to £53, driven by higher prices and increased demand for heating during last year's cold weather. The average profit margin for supplying energy to households in 2012 was 4.3%, up from 2.8% in 2011, with total profits from supplying energy to households and businesses rising from £1.25bn to £1.6bn last year.

"The sort of things we would consider are, does it have an adverse impact on consumers and on the investment that's needed?

"It is obviously necessary to allow companies to recover the revenues that they need to be able to run their businesses effectively. They should have no guarantee of profits but an efficient business serving customers should be able to recover the costs that they incur. So any arrangement that doesn't allow them to do that potentially puts at risk investment in the industry."

His comments came a day after Ofgem published a report which found that profits per customer rose by 77% last year, from £30 to £53, driven by higher prices and increased demand for heating during last year's cold weather.

The average profit margin for supplying energy to households in 2012 was 4.3%, up from 2.8% in 2011, with total profits from supplying energy to households and businesses rising from £1.25bn to £1.6bn last year.

webTitle: China slowdown triggers profit warnings at Remy Cointreau and Hugo Boss

fields.standfirst: Shares in premium cognac maker and German fashion house slide amid flagging sales in Chinese economy
fields.body:
Slowing growth in China will hit profits at French spirits group Remy Cointreau and German fashion house Hugo Boss, the two companies warned.

Shares in Remy Cointreau fell 9% on Tuesday morning after it said flagging sales in the world's second largest economy would trigger a double-digit decline in full-year operating profit.

The producer of champagne and premium cognac and other spirits said operating profit fell 6.2% to €132.7m (£111m) in the six months to 30 September, while sales fell 6.3% to €558m.

"Although the group maintained a strong momentum in the US and Europe, this did not offset the slowdown recorded in China," the company said.

"In an uncertain economic environment in Europe and against the backdrop of a sharp slowdown in China, which remains impacted by high inventory levels in distribution and poor short-term visibility, the business environment will be less favourable in the second half of the year."

It said it remained confident in the medium and long-term outlook for China.

Meanwhile Hugo Boss said it would not meet its target of €750m in core operating profit in 2015 as a result of slower-than-expected growth in China and Europe.

Its chief executive, Claus-Dietrich Lahrs, said global growth rates had turned out to be lower than the company had expected when it made its 2015 forecasts at the end of 2011.

"A particular concern is China," he told investors at an event in Hong Kong.

"Compared to what we were used to, the long period of low-hanging fruit, China came down to a rather disappointing growth rate for the luxury industry in 2013." The company's shares fell 6%.

webTitle: Severn Trent says below-inflation price rises keeping bad debts under control

fields.standfirst: Water company says debts among lowest in industry despite high unemployment and poverty in Midlands and mid-Wales
fields.body:
Severn Trent said below-inflation prices rises were helping the water company keep its bad debts under control despite serving some of the most impoverished households in the UK.

The Coventry-based company said its average combined bills were the lowest in England and Wales at £335 a year at a time when cost of living pressures were bearing down on its customers in the Midlands and mid-Wales.

Underlying pre-tax profit fell 5.8% to £141.3m in the six months to 30 September, following below-inflation price rises of 2% from 1 April.

The company, which provides water to about 7 million people, pledged to keep price rises below inflation next year.

Bad debts were flat at 2.2% of turnover over the period, one of the lowest in the industry, according to Severn Trent.

The chief executive, Tony Wray, said the number of people failing to pay debts was limited despite some of the highest levels of unemployment and poverty in the UK among its customer base.

"Many customers are facing serious cost of living pressures and we aim to keep bills to the minimum with below-inflation rises across the current regulatory period and help for customers through our range of social tariffs. We remain committed to keeping customers' bills down," he added.

Turnover in the first half rose 0.5% to £922.4m, while pre-tax profit jumped 68.6% to £191.2 when a one-off £44m refund for tax overpayments was included.

The company recommended an interim dividend of 32.16p a share, up 6%.

Severn Trent said it was on track to submit its business plan for the next five-year regulatory period to Ofwat next week, which would "reflect our customers' priorities and strike the right balance between affordability, investment to maintain and improve our service and the environment, and appropriate returns for shareholders".

Severn Trent announced last week that BT Group's Liv Garfield would join the FTSE 100 company as chief executive in spring 2014, following Wray's retirement.

Wray said on Tuesday he would work closely with Garfield to ensure a smooth handover of responsibilities.

The company invested £269m in capital projects in the first six months of the year, up 12.5%, which it said had helped to reduce supply interruptions, sewer flooding and serious pollution incidents.
